Schrody
  • How to Play
  • Gates

Schrody

You are Schrody, Schrodinger's cat. You have been put in a box by your master for an experiment. Now you are in a superposition - half dead half alive. You must remain alive and be 100% alive when your master opens the box to see the result of his experiment. In the box there are some quantum gates and you must use them to transition from the superposition state to the |ALIVE> state. However, if you are still in a suprposition when Dr. Schrodinger opens the box, you still have a random chance (depending on the suerposition) of remaining alive and passing to the next level.

How to play

Use the arrow keys to move around and jump.


In each level you start in a different superposition of |DEAD> and |ALIVE> (|0> = |DEAD>, |1> = |ALIVE>). The superposition is shown to you in the Bloch sphere at the top left of the screen and in the formula at the top of the screen.


In the box there are several quantum gates. Each time you collect a gate your superposition changes accordingly. The goal is to transition, using the quantum gates, from the superposition state to the |ALIVE> state (|1>).

The level ends when:

  1. You are no longer in a superposition but in a defined state. If you are in the state |ALIVE> you pass the level. If you are in the state |DEAD> you fail.
  2. The time ends. If you are still in a superposition when the time ends and Dr. Schrodinger looks in the box your state colapses randomly to either |DEAD> or |ALIVE>. If you are in luck and you get the state alive you can pass the level. If not you fail.


Once the level has ended press space to pass to the next level or restart the level

Gates

contact@nirosoful.com

Pauli X Gate

The Pauli X gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}0 & 1\\1 & 0\end{bmatrix}

Its efect is to swap the coeficients of the state vector: $a|0\rangle + b|1\rangle$ becomes $b|0\rangle + a|1\rangle$

On the Bloch sphere this corresponds to a rotation around the X axis of $\pi \ \mathrm{rad}$ ($180^\circ$)

Pauli Y Gate

The Pauli Y gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}0 & -i\\i & 0\end{bmatrix}

On the Bloch sphere this corresponds to a rotation around the Y axis of $\pi \ \mathrm{rad}$ ($180^\circ$)

Pauly Z Gate

The Pauli Z gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & -1\end{bmatrix}

Its efect is to change the sign of the $|1\rangle$ component: $a|0\rangle + b|1\rangle$ becomes $a|0\rangle - b|1\rangle$

On the Bloch sphere this corresponds to a rotation around the Z axis of $\pi \ \mathrm{rad}$ ($180^\circ$)

The Hadamard Gate

The Hadamard gate has the matrix representation $\frac{1}{ \sqrt{2} }$ \begin{bmatrix}1 & 1\\1 & -1\end{bmatrix}

It us used pimarily to create or destry superpositions

On the Bloch sphere applying it corresponds to a rotation of $\pi \ \mathrm{rad}$ around an axis in the XZ plane that passes througn the origin and is angled at $45^\circ$ relative to the X and Z axes.

The S Gate

The S gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & i\end{bmatrix}

On the Bloch sphere applying it corresponds to a rotation of $\frac{\pi}{2} \ \mathrm{rad}$ around the Z axis.

The T Gate

The T gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & e^{i \pi/4}\end{bmatrix}

On the Bloch sphere applying it corresponds to a rotation of $\frac{\pi}{4} \ \mathrm{rad}$ around the Z axis.

The S Dagger Gate

The S dagger gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & -i\end{bmatrix}

On the Bloch sphere applying it corresponds to a rotation of $-\frac{\pi}{2} \ \mathrm{rad}$ around the Z axis.

The T Dagger Gate

The T dagger gate has the matrix representation \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0\\0 & e^{-i \pi/4}\end{bmatrix}

On the Bloch sphere applying it corresponds to a rotation of $-\frac{\pi}{4} \ \mathrm{rad}$ around the Z axis.
